images.altText: On July 16, 1790 President George Washington signed the Residence Act. The Act mandated that the site of the new US capital not exceed 259 sq km (100 sq mi), and that it should lie on the Potomac River somewhere near the Anacostia River. The city took 10 years to build, and the federal government moved into Washington, D.C., in 1800. Washington died in 1799 and never lived in the city bearing his name.
images.caption: On July 16, 1790 President George Washington signed the Residence Act. The city took 10 years to build, and the federal government moved into Washington, D.C., in 1800. Washington died in 1799 and never lived in the city bearing his name.

images.altText: The lighting of this stone lantern signals the beginning of the annual Cherry Blossom festival in Washington, D.C. Japan presented it to the city on March 30, 1954, as a symbol of the enduring cultural partnership between the two countries. Photo courtesy of the National Park Service.

images.altText: The Washington Monument in Washington, D.C., is 169 m (555 ft) tall. A difference in the shading of the marble at approximately 48 m (150 ft) shows where construction was halted and later resumed with marble from a different source. Photo courtesy of the National Park Service.
images.caption: The Washington Monument in Washington, D.C., is 169 m (555 ft) tall. A difference in the shading of the marble at approximately 48 m (150 ft) shows where construction was halted and later resumed with marble from a different source. Photo courtesy of the National Park Service.

images.altText: On April 13, 1943, President Franklin Delano Roosevelt dedicated the Thomas Jefferson Memorial, which was designed by architect John Russell Pope.
images.caption: On April 13, 1943, President Franklin Delano Roosevelt dedicated the Thomas Jefferson Memorial, which was designed by architect John Russell Pope.

images.altText: The Lincoln Memorial in Washington, D.C., was dedicated in 1922 and is modeled after the Parthenon in Athens, Greece. It is 30 m tall (99 ft), 57.m long (190 ft), and 36.5 m wide (120 ft) and includes 36 Doric columns, one for each of the 36 states in the Union at the time of Lincoln's death. Photo courtesy of the National Park Service/Carol Highsmith.
images.caption: The Lincoln Memorial in Washington, D.C., was dedicated in 1922 and is modeled after the Parthenon in Athens, Greece. It is 30 m tall (99 ft), 57.m long (190 ft), and 36.5 m wide (120 ft) and includes 36 Doric columns, one for each of the 36 states in the Union at the time of Lincoln's death. Photo courtesy of the National Park Service/Carol Highsmith.

images.altText: The Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr. Memorial was dedicated on 28 August 2011, the 48th anniversary of the March on Washington for Jobs and Freedom. The memorial is located in West Potomac Park at 1964 Independence Avenue, S.W., in Washington, D.C., referencing the year the Civil Rights Act of 1964 became law.
images.caption: The Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr. Memorial was dedicated on 28 August 2011, the 48th anniversary of the March on Washington for Jobs and Freedom. The memorial is located in West Potomac Park at 1964 Independence Avenue, S.W., in Washington, D.C., referencing the year the Civil Rights Act of 1964 became law.

images.altText: A wall of 4,048 gold stars – each representing 100 killed – at the World War II Memorial in Washington, D.C. Photo courtesy of the National Park Service.
images.caption: A wall of 4,048 gold stars – each representing 100 killed – at the World War II Memorial in Washington, D.C. Photo courtesy of the National Park Service.

images.altText: Secretary of War Edwin Stanton established Arlington National Cemetery on 15 June 1864. Over 400,000 service members (and their eligible dependents) from all of America’s major wars are interred in Arlington’s 639 acres (259 ha; almost exactly 1 sq mi).
images.caption: Secretary of War Edwin Stanton established Arlington National Cemetery on 15 June 1864. Over 400,000 service members (and their eligible dependents) from all of America’s major wars are interred in Arlington’s 639 acres (259 ha; almost exactly 1 sq mi).

images.caption: The Tomb of the Unknown Soldier in Arlington National Cemetery in Virginia.

images.altText: The Marine Corps War Memorial in Washington, D.C.
images.caption: The Marine Corps War Memorial in Washington, D.C.

images.altText: President Lyndon B. Johnson dedicated the Hall of Heroes at the Pentagon on 14 May 1968 to display the name of every Medal of Honor recipient.
images.caption: President Lyndon B. Johnson dedicated the Hall of Heroes at the Pentagon on 14 May 1968 to display the name of every Medal of Honor recipient.

images.altText: Today marks the 250th birthday of the United States Navy. In 1775, the Continental Congress established a naval force to work with privateers to attack British commerce and military ships. The Navy and Marine Memorial (pictured) in Washington, D.C., was completed in 1939 and honors sailors who died at sea while serving the country. The statue by Italian sculptor Ernesto Begni del Piatta has seven seagulls that represent sacrifice on the seven seas, as well as crashing waves that represent the dangers at sea.
images.caption: Today marks the 250th birthday of the United States Navy. In 1775, the Continental Congress established a naval force to work with privateers to attack British commerce and military ships. The Navy and Marine Memorial (pictured) in Washington, D.C., was completed in 1939 and honors sailors who died at sea while serving the country. The statue by Italian sculptor Ernesto Begni del Piatta has seven seagulls that represent sacrifice on the seven seas, as well as crashing waves that represent the dangers at sea.

images.altText: Fourth of July fireworks in Washington, D.C., with a view of the Lincoln Memorial, the Washington Monument, and the US Capitol.
images.caption: Fourth of July fireworks in Washington, D.C., with a view of the Lincoln Memorial, the Washington Monument, and the US Capitol.

images.altText: The Library of Congress in Washington, D.C., is the largest library in the world, with more than 167 million items (as of 2018). Its collections are home to materials in over 450 languages and include books, newspapers, magazines, sheet music, sound and video recordings, photographic images, artwork, architectural drawings, and copyright data. Image courtesy of the Architect of the Capital.

Its collections are home to materials in over 450 languages and include books, newspapers, magazines, sheet music, sound and video recordings, photographic images, artwork, architectural drawings, and copyright data. Image courtesy of the Architect of the Capital.

images.altText: The Smithsonian Castle in Washington, D.C. The US Congress established the Smithsonian Institution in 1846 with money from the estate of English scientist James Smithson that was provided for "the increase and diffusion of knowledge." The castle was built in 1847 and remains the Smithsonian's headquarters. Photo courtesy of the Smithsonian Institution.
images.caption: The Smithsonian Castle in Washington, D.C. The US Congress established the Smithsonian Institution in 1846 with money from the estate of English scientist James Smithson that was provided for "the increase and diffusion of knowledge." The castle was built in 1847 and remains the Smithsonian's headquarters. Photo courtesy of the Smithsonian Institution.

images.altText: In 1916, Alice Paul founded the National Woman’s Party (NWP) to fight for an amendment granting women the right to vote. The NWP became an educational organization in 1997, and in 2016, the group donated its original headquarters (pictured here) in Washington, D.C., to the National Park Service. The house was named the Belmont-Paul Women’s Equality National Monument, in honor of Paul and NWP president and benefactor Alva Belmont.
images.caption: In 1916, Alice Paul founded the National Woman’s Party (NWP) to fight for an amendment granting women the right to vote. The NWP became an educational organization in 1997, and in 2016, the group donated its original headquarters (pictured here) in Washington, D.C., to the National Park Service. The house was named the Belmont-Paul Women’s Equality National Monument, in honor of Paul and NWP president and benefactor Alva Belmont.

images.altText: Memorial plaza, statue, and fountain on Theodore Roosevelt Island in Washington, D.C. Photo courtesy of the National Park Service.
images.caption: Memorial plaza, statue, and fountain on Theodore Roosevelt Island in Washington, D.C. Photo courtesy of the National Park Service.

images.altText: Statue honoring Sacagawea, a member of the Lemhi-Shoshone tribe, who was crucial to the success of the Lewis and Clark expedition (1804-06) to the Louisiana Purchase territory. Sacagawea’s granddaughter was the model for this statue that stands in the US Capitol Visitor’s Center.   Photo courtesy of US Capitol Visitor's Center.
images.caption: Statue honoring Sacagawea, a member of the Lemhi-Shoshone tribe, who was crucial to the success of the Lewis and Clark expedition (1804-06) to the Louisiana Purchase territory. Sacagawea’s granddaughter was the model for this statue that stands in the US Capitol Visitor’s Center.   Photo courtesy of US Capitol Visitor's Center.

images.altText: On October 14, 1947, US Air Force Capt. Charles E. “Chuck” Yeager broke the sound barrier in level flight in this Bell X-1, a single-engine, single-seat, mid-wing rocket plane nicknamed the “Glamorous Glennis” for his wife. The X-1 is displayed at the Smithsonian Air and Space Museum in Washington, D.C.
images.caption: On October 14, 1947, US Air Force Capt. Charles E. “Chuck” Yeager broke the sound barrier in level flight in this Bell X-1, a single-engine, single-seat, mid-wing rocket plane nicknamed the “Glamorous Glennis” for his wife. The X-1 is displayed at the Smithsonian Air and Space Museum in Washington, D.C.

images.altText: In April 1972, the first pandas in the United States arrived at the Smithsonian National Zoo as an act of goodwill from China after President Richard Nixon's state visit. These black-and-white bears are native to the mountain ranges and bamboo forests of south central China. Photo courtesy of the Smithsonian National Zoo.
images.caption: In April 1972, the first pandas in the United States arrived at the Smithsonian National Zoo as an act of goodwill from China after President Richard Nixon's state visit. These black-and-white bears are native to the mountain ranges and bamboo forests of south central China. Photo courtesy of the Smithsonian National Zoo.

images.altText: Now a national monument, Fort McHenry in Baltimore, Maryland, is known for successfully defending Baltimore Harbor against the British navy during the War of 1812. The flying of the fort’s flag after 25 hours of continuous bombardment signaled US victory and inspired Francis Scott Key to compose the poem “Defence of Fort M’Henry,” which was later set to music and became known as “The Star-Spangled Banner,” the US national anthem.
images.caption: Now a national monument, Fort McHenry in Baltimore, Maryland, is known for successfully defending Baltimore Harbor against the British navy during the War of 1812. The flying of the fort’s flag after 25 hours of continuous bombardment signaled US victory and inspired Francis Scott Key to compose the poem “Defence of Fort M’Henry,” which was later set to music and became known as “The Star-Spangled Banner,” the US national anthem.

images.altText: The front view of Monticello, Thomas Jefferson's plantation home, near Charlottesville, Virginia. The third president of the United States completed the original house in 1772. In 1794, he began to rebuild the structure, blending his own architectural style with his favorite European designs. Remodeling continued on and off for the remainder of his life.
images.caption: The front view of Monticello, Thomas Jefferson's plantation home, near Charlottesville, Virginia. The third president of the United States completed the original house in 1772. In 1794, he began to rebuild the structure, blending his own architectural style with his favorite European designs. Remodeling continued on and off for the remainder of his life.

images.altText: The Mayflower II at State Pier in Plymouth, Massachusetts. The ship is a replica of the 17th-century Mayflower that transported the Pilgrims to the New World.
images.caption: The Mayflower II at State Pier in Plymouth, Massachusetts. The ship is a replica of the 17th-century Mayflower that transported the Pilgrims to the New World.

images.altText: Built between 1872 and 1877, Trinity Church in Boston, Massachusetts, has been honored as one of the "Ten Most Significant Buildings in the United States."
images.caption: Built between 1872 and 1877, Trinity Church in Boston, Massachusetts, has been honored as one of the "Ten Most Significant Buildings in the United States."

images.altText: The USS Constitution, docked at Pier 1 of the Charleston Navy Yard in Boston, Massachusetts, is the oldest floating commissioned naval vessel in the world. Launched in 1797, it was one of the six original frigates built for the US Navy.
images.caption: The USS Constitution, docked at Pier 1 of the Charleston Navy Yard in Boston, Massachusetts, is the oldest floating commissioned naval vessel in the world. Launched in 1797, it was one of the six original frigates built for the US Navy.

images.altText: Statue of Paul Revere in front of the Old North Church in Boston, Massachusetts. Image courtesy of the US National Park Service.
images.caption: Statue of Paul Revere in front of the Old North Church in Boston, Massachusetts. Image courtesy of the US National Park Service.

images.altText: On 17 June 1775, the American Revolution’s first major battle occurred outside Boston, Massachusetts, and was dubbed “The Battle of Bunker Hill,” even though the original objective of both sides was nearby Breed’s Hill. The Bunker Hill Monument, built between 1825 and 1843 on Breed’s Hill, is a 67-m (221-ft) high granite obelisk with a statue of William Prescott, the leader of the American troops.
images.caption: On 17 June 1775, the American Revolution’s first major battle occurred outside Boston, Massachusetts, and was dubbed “The Battle of Bunker Hill,” even though the original objective of both sides was nearby Breed’s Hill. The Bunker Hill Monument, built between 1825 and 1843 on Breed’s Hill, is a 67-m (221-ft) high granite obelisk with a statue of William Prescott, the leader of the American troops.

images.altText: Walden Pond, a  26-ha (64-acre) body of water near Concord, Massachusetts. Writer Henry David Thoreau (1817–1862), spent two years, two months, and two days living in a cabin next to the pond, which provided the foundation for his famous 1854 work, Walden or Life in the Woods.
images.caption: Walden Pond, a  26-ha (64-acre) body of water near Concord, Massachusetts. Writer Henry David Thoreau (1817–1862), spent two years, two months, and two days living in a cabin next to the pond, which provided the foundation for his famous 1854 work, Walden or Life in the Woods.

images.altText: A replica of the Henry David Thoreau cabin at Walden Pond near Concord, Massachusetts.
images.caption: A replica of the Henry David Thoreau cabin at Walden Pond near Concord, Massachusetts.

images.altText: The Statue of Liberty in New York Harbor was originally a dull copper color, but shortly after 1900, a green patina caused by the oxidation of the copper skin began to spread. As early as 1902 it was mentioned in the press; by 1906 it had entirely covered the statue. Photo courtesy of the National Park Service.
images.caption: The Statue of Liberty in New York Harbor was originally a dull copper color, but shortly after 1900, a green patina caused by the oxidation of the copper skin began to spread. As early as 1902 it was mentioned in the press; by 1906 it had entirely covered the statue. Photo courtesy of the National Park Service.

images.altText: The entrance to the main building of the Ellis Island National Immigration Museum in New York. Image courtesy of the US National Park Service.
images.caption: The entrance to the main building of the Ellis Island National Immigration Museum in New York. Image courtesy of the US National Park Service.

images.altText: Located in New York City, New York, the Metropolitan Opera is the largest opera house in the world by capacity, with 3,800 seats and 175 standing room places. Known as “The Met,” it was founded in 1883 and is the largest classical music organization in North America. It moved to its current location at Lincoln Center (pictured) in 1966.
images.caption: Located in New York City, New York, the Metropolitan Opera is the largest opera house in the world by capacity, with 3,800 seats and 175 standing room places. Known as “The Met,” it was founded in 1883 and is the largest classical music organization in North America. It moved to its current location at Lincoln Center (pictured) in 1966.

images.altText: This statue in Seneca Falls, New York, depicts the first meeting of the two iconic leaders of the American women's suffrage movement, Susan B. Anthony and Elizabeth Cady Stanton. Photo courtesy of the US National Park Service.
images.caption: This statue in Seneca Falls, New York, depicts the first meeting of the two iconic leaders of the American women's suffrage movement, Susan B. Anthony and Elizabeth Cady Stanton. Photo courtesy of the US National Park Service.

images.altText: Independence Hall in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, was the scene of the signing of both the Declaration of Independence and the US Constitution. Two buildings flank the hall: Congress Hall, on the right, housed the US Congress from 1790 to 1800, and to the left is Old City Hall, where the US Supreme Court presided in the 1790s. Photo courtesy of the US National Park Service.
images.caption: Independence Hall in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, was the scene of the signing of both the Declaration of Independence and the US Constitution. Two buildings flank the hall: Congress Hall, on the right, housed the US Congress from 1790 to 1800, and to the left is Old City Hall, where the US Supreme Court presided in the 1790s. Photo courtesy of the US National Park Service.

images.altText: The Assembly Room of the Pennsylvania State House in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, served as the meeting place for the state assembly until the state capital was moved in 1799. In 1776, the Continental Congress declared the United States independent in this room, and in 1787, the US Constitution was debated and signed here. Photo courtesy of the US National Park Service.
images.caption: The Assembly Room of the Pennsylvania State House in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, served as the meeting place for the state assembly until the state capital was moved in 1799. In 1776, the Continental Congress declared the United States independent in this room, and in 1787, the US Constitution was debated and signed here. Photo courtesy of the US National Park Service.

images.altText: The Moravian Church Settlements can be found in Denmark, Germany, the United Kingdom, and Bethlehem, Pennsylvania. The Bethlehem settlement’s waterworks (pictured) became America’s first pumped municipal water system when it was built in 1762, and it remained in use until the 1830s.
images.caption: The Moravian Church Settlements can be found in Denmark, Germany, the United Kingdom, and Bethlehem, Pennsylvania. The Bethlehem settlement’s waterworks (pictured) became America’s first pumped municipal water system when it was built in 1762, and it remained in use until the 1830s.

images.altText: A view of the Round Tops as seen from a cannon in Gettysburg National Military Park in Gettysburg, Pennsylvania. The three-day Battle of Gettysburg (1-3 July 1863) in the US Civil War was the largest ever battle fought in the Western Hemisphere, involving roughly 175,000 Union and Confederate soldiers. Image courtesy of the US National Park Service.
images.caption: A view of the Round Tops as seen from a cannon in Gettysburg National Military Park in Gettysburg, Pennsylvania. The three-day Battle of Gettysburg (1-3 July 1863) in the US Civil War was the largest ever battle fought in the Western Hemisphere, involving roughly 175,000 Union and Confederate soldiers. Image courtesy of the US National Park Service.

images.altText: A view of the modern palisades marking the 1607 James Fort location at the Jamestown National Historic Site in Virginia. The statue inside the fort is of John Smith, who played an important role in establishing Jamestown as the first permanent English settlement in America. Photo courtesy of the National Park Service.
images.caption: A view of the modern palisades marking the 1607 James Fort location at the Jamestown National Historic Site in Virginia. The statue inside the fort is of John Smith, who played an important role in establishing Jamestown as the first permanent English settlement in America. Photo courtesy of the National Park Service.

images.altText: Statue of John Smith at Jamestown National Historic Site, Virginia. Smith was a leader of the Virginia colony from September 1608 to August 1609 and was the first English explorer to map the Chesapeake Bay area. Photo courtesy of the National Park Service.
images.caption: Statue of John Smith at Jamestown National Historic Site, Virginia. Smith was a leader of the Virginia colony from September 1608 to August 1609 and was the first English explorer to map the Chesapeake Bay area. Photo courtesy of the National Park Service.

images.altText: The Yorktown Victory Monument in Yorktown, Virginia, commemorates the decisive 1781 battle of the Revolutionary War in which the combined forces of the United States and France defeated those of Great Britain and set the stage for British recognition of American independence. Photo courtesy of the National Park Service.
images.caption: The Yorktown Victory Monument in Yorktown, Virginia, commemorates the decisive 1781 battle of the Revolutionary War in which the combined forces of the United States and France defeated those of Great Britain and set the stage for British recognition of American independence. Photo courtesy of the National Park Service.

images.altText: The entrance to Berkeley Plantation in Virginia, which was the birthplace of Benjamin Harrison V, a signer of the Declaration of Independence and a governor of Virginia;  the birthplace of William Henry Harrison, the ninth US president; and the ancestral home of Benjamin Harrison, the 23rd president.
images.caption: The entrance to Berkeley Plantation in Virginia, which was the birthplace of Benjamin Harrison V, a signer of the Declaration of Independence and a governor of Virginia;  the birthplace of William Henry Harrison, the ninth US president; and the ancestral home of Benjamin Harrison, the 23rd president.

images.altText: A memorial to the composition "Taps" at Berkeley Plantation in Virginia, where it was first played. During the Civil War, Union General Daniel Butterfield and his bugler O.W. Norton wrote "Taps" while camped here, to honor the troops. The plaintive military tune is now played at the end of day and at funerals.
images.caption: A memorial to the composition "Taps" at Berkeley Plantation in Virginia, where it was first played. During the Civil War, Union General Daniel Butterfield and his bugler O.W. Norton wrote "Taps" while camped here, to honor the troops. The plaintive military tune is now played at the end of day and at funerals.

images.altText: In 1781, representatives from the American, British, and French armies (the latter allies to the Americans) met at Moore House (pictured) in Yorktown, Virginia, to negotiate surrender terms to end the Revolutionary War. On October 19, 1781, American General George Washington and British Lieutenant General Charles Cornwallis signed the Articles, directing the disposition of troops, artillery, and arms.
images.caption: In 1781, representatives from the American, British, and French armies (the latter allies to the Americans) met at Moore House (pictured) in Yorktown, Virginia, to negotiate surrender terms to end the Revolutionary War. On October 19, 1781, American General George Washington and British Lieutenant General Charles Cornwallis signed the Articles, directing the disposition of troops, artillery, and arms.

images.altText: John Brown’s Fort in Harpers Ferry, West Virginia. The building was originally constructed in 1848 for use as a guard and fire engine house. Photo courtesy of the National Park Service.
images.caption: John Brown’s Fort in Harpers Ferry, West Virginia. The building was originally constructed in 1848 for use as a guard and fire engine house. Photo courtesy of the National Park Service.

images.altText: On 17 December 1903, Orville and Wilbur Wright flew the first successful manned, powered, controlled, heavier-than-air flight at Kitty Hawk, North Carolina. The Wright Brothers National Memorial, in Kill Devil Hills near Kitty Hawk, is located where the brothers tested their flying machines for three years before the successful 1903 flight.
images.caption: On 17 December 1903, Orville and Wilbur Wright flew the first successful manned, powered, controlled, heavier-than-air flight at Kitty Hawk, North Carolina. The Wright Brothers National Memorial, in Kill Devil Hills near Kitty Hawk, is located where the brothers tested their flying machines for three years before the successful 1903 flight.

images.altText: Biltmore House is the largest privately owned home in the United States and is also a historic house museum. Built for George Vanderbilt II between 1889 and 1895, this French-Renaissance-style chateau with 250 rooms is located in the Blue Ridge Mountains in Asheville, North Carolina.
images.caption: Biltmore House is the largest privately owned home in the United States and is also a historic house museum. Built for George Vanderbilt II between 1889 and 1895, this French-Renaissance-style chateau with 250 rooms is located in the Blue Ridge Mountains in Asheville, North Carolina.

images.altText: Marker in Key West, Florida, proclaiming the southernmost point in the continental United States. (The southernmost point in the entire country is in Hawaii.)
images.caption: Marker in Key West, Florida, proclaiming the southernmost point in the continental United States. (The southernmost point in the entire country is in Hawaii.)

images.altText: The Gateway Arch in St. Louis, Missouri, the iconic symbol of the city. The monument honors the westward expansion of the United States, much of which began in this city. Built between 1963 and 1965 (but not opened to the public until 1967), the stainless steel-sheathed structure is hollow to accommodate a unique tram system that takes visitors to an observation deck at the top.
images.caption: The Gateway Arch in St. Louis, Missouri, the iconic symbol of the city. The monument honors the westward expansion of the United States, much of which began in this city. Built between 1963 and 1965 (but not opened to the public until 1967), the stainless steel-sheathed structure is hollow to accommodate a unique tram system that takes visitors to an observation deck at the top.

images.altText: Stalactites and stalagmites made of travertine can be seen on the Frozen Niagara tour of Mammoth Cave in Kentucky. Travertine, or traveling stone, is made of limestone that has crystalized from dripping water. Image courtesy of the US National Park Service.
images.caption: Stalactites and stalagmites made of travertine can be seen on the Frozen Niagara tour of Mammoth Cave in Kentucky. Travertine, or traveling stone, is made of limestone that has crystalized from dripping water. Image courtesy of the US National Park Service.

images.altText: Mount Rushmore National Memorial in the Black Hills of South Dakota features the sculptures of four US presidents: George Washington, Thomas Jefferson, Theodore Roosevelt, and Abraham Lincoln. Gutzon Borglum sculpted the monument between 1927 and 1941 but never finished it. Image courtesy of the US National Park Service.
images.caption: Mount Rushmore National Memorial in the Black Hills of South Dakota features the sculptures of four US presidents: George Washington, Thomas Jefferson, Theodore Roosevelt, and Abraham Lincoln. Gutzon Borglum sculpted the monument between 1927 and 1941 but never finished it. Image courtesy of the US National Park Service.

images.altText: Located near Vermillion, South Dakota, Spirit Mound is described in Sioux, Omaha, and Otoe tribal stories as a place where spirits lived. Captain Meriwether Lewis and Second Lieutenant William Clark of the famed Lewis and Clark Expedition climbed the mound on August 25, 1804, and recorded in their report the rocks and wildlife they found and the view of the prairie below. Today Spirit Mound is part of the Lewis and Clark National Historic Trail, which extends from Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, to Astoria, Oregon.
images.caption: Located near Vermillion, South Dakota, Spirit Mound is described in Sioux, Omaha, and Otoe tribal stories as a place where spirits lived. Captain Meriwether Lewis and Second Lieutenant William Clark of the famed Lewis and Clark Expedition climbed the mound on August 25, 1804, and recorded in their report the rocks and wildlife they found and the view of the prairie below. Today Spirit Mound is part of the Lewis and Clark National Historic Trail, which extends from Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, to Astoria, Oregon.

images.altText: Close-up of Cliff Palace in Mesa Verde National Park, Colorado. The park is home to some of the best-preserved Ancestral Puebloan (Anasazi) archaeological sites in the US. Cliff Palace was continuously occupied from about 1190 to 1260 and abandoned around 1300. Image courtesy of the US National Park Service.
images.caption: Close-up of Cliff Palace in Mesa Verde National Park, Colorado. The park is home to some of the best-preserved Ancestral Puebloan (Anasazi) archaeological sites in the US. images.caption: Completed in 1935, Hoover Dam on the Colorado River straddles the Arizona-Nevada border.

images.altText: The Lime Kiln Lighthouse on San Juan Island in Washington State, named for the area’s once-busy lime kilns and mines, consists of an octagonal tower and two outer buildings. Built in 1919, it is currently used as a research lab for studying orca whales. The area around the lighthouse is considered one of the best places in the world to view orcas from land, and Lime Kiln State Park, known as the first “whale watch park,” was established there in 1984.
images.caption: The Lime Kiln Lighthouse on San Juan Island in Washington State, named for the area’s once-busy lime kilns and mines, consists of an octagonal tower and two outer buildings. Built in 1919, it is currently used as a research lab for studying orca whales. The area around the lighthouse is considered one of the best places in the world to view orcas from land, and Lime Kiln State Park, known as the first “whale watch park,” was established there in 1984.

images.altText: Mount Rainier is an active stratovolcano and the highest mountain in Washington State. Standing at 4,392 m (14,410 ft), the volcano has not had a significant eruption in the past 500 years, but it is considered potentially the most dangerous volcano in the Cascade Range due to its great height, frequent earthquakes, and glacier mantle, as well as its proximity to major urban areas (Seattle and Tacoma, Washington, and Portland, Oregon). In 1899, Mount Rainier was declared the nation’s fifth national park, named for Royal Navy Admiral Peter Rainier.
images.caption: Mount Rainier is an active stratovolcano and the highest mountain in Washington State. Standing at 4,392 m (14,410 ft), the volcano has not had a significant eruption in the past 500 years, but it is considered potentially the most dangerous volcano in the Cascade Range due to its great height, frequent earthquakes, and glacier mantle, as well as its proximity to major urban areas (Seattle and Tacoma, Washington, and Portland, Oregon). In 1899, Mount Rainier was declared the nation’s fifth national park, named for Royal Navy Admiral Peter Rainier.

images.altText: Olympic National Park, located in Washington State, United States, has four distinct climate zones: coastline, rainforest, alpine meadows and glaciated peaks. A national park since 1938, it is home to both the wettest area in the continental US and the longest undeveloped coastline, and Mount Olympus (pictured) in the park has the most glacial ice of any non-volcanic peak in the contiguous US.
images.caption: Olympic National Park, located in Washington State, United States, has four distinct climate zones: coastline, rainforest, alpine meadows and glaciated peaks. A national park since 1938, it is home to both the wettest area in the continental US and the longest undeveloped coastline, and Mount Olympus (pictured) in the park has the most glacial ice of any non-volcanic peak in the contiguous US.

images.altText: The Mesquite Flat Sand Dunes in Death Valley National Park, California. At 86 m (282 ft) below sea level, Death Valley is one of the hottest, driest places on the planet. On average, the area sees only about 5 cm (2 in) of rain a year, and summer temperatures routinely soar above 38 degrees Celsius (100 degrees Fahrenheit). Photo courtesy of the US Geologic Survey/ Paul Stone.

images.altText: The General Sherman Tree is located in Sequoia National Park in California. The tree is the largest in the world as measured by wood volume and is approximately 2,200 years old. It stands 83 m (275 ft)  tall and is over 11 m (36 ft) in diameter at the base.  Photograph courtesy of the National Park Service.

media.label: 2024 population pyramid
media.altText:
This is the population pyramid for United States. A population pyramid illustrates the age and sex structure of a country's population and may provide insights about political and social stability, as well as economic development. The population is distributed along the horizontal axis, with males shown on the left and females on the right. The male and female populations are broken down into 5-year age groups represented as horizontal bars along the vertical axis, with the youngest age groups at the bottom and the oldest at the top. The shape of the population pyramid gradually evolves over time based on fertility, mortality, and international migration trends.

For additional information, please see the entry for Population pyramid on the Definitions and Notes page.

nodes.name: Natural hazards
nodes.data:
tsunamis; volcanoes; earthquake activity around Pacific Basin; hurricanes along the Atlantic and Gulf of America coasts; tornadoes in the Midwest and Southeast; mud slides in California; forest fires in the west; flooding; permafrost in northern Alaska is a major impediment to development

volcanism: volcanic activity in the Hawaiian Islands, Western Alaska, the Pacific Northwest, and in the Northern Mariana Islands; Mauna Loa (4,170 m) in Hawaii and Mount Rainier (4,392 m) in Washington have been deemed Decade Volcanoes by the International Association of Volcanology and Chemistry of the Earth's Interior, worthy of study due to their explosive history and close proximity to human populations; Pavlof (2,519 m) is the most active volcano in Alaska's Aleutian Arc and poses a significant threat to intercontinental air travel; St. Helens (2,549 m), famous for the devastating 1980 eruption, remains active today; other historically active volcanoes are mostly concentrated in the Aleutian arc and Hawaii, including (in Alaska) Aniakchak, Augustine, Chiginagak, Fourpeaked, Iliamna, Katmai, Kupreanof, Martin, Novarupta, Redoubt, Spurr, Wrangell, Trident, Ugashik-Peulik, Ukinrek Maars, Veniaminof, (in Hawaii) Haleakala, Kilauea, Loihi, (in the Northern Mariana Islands) Anatahan, (in the Pacific Northwest) Mount Baker, and Mount Hood; see note 2 under "Geography - note"

nodes.name: Military service age and obligation
nodes.data:
17 years of age (under 18 with parental consent) for voluntary service for men and women; maximum enlistment age 35 (Army), 42 (Air Force/Space Force), 41 (Navy), 28 (Marines), 41 (Coast Guard); 8-year initial service obligation, including 2-5 years active duty depending on the particular military service (2025)

note 1: the US military has been all-volunteer since 1973, but an act of Congress can reinstate the draft in case of a national emergency; males aged 18-25 must register with Selective Service

note 2: all military occupations and positions open to women; in 2022, women comprised 17.5% of the total US regular military personnel

note 3: non-citizens living permanently and legally in the US may join as enlisted personnel; they must have permission to work in the US, a high school diploma, and speak, read, and write English fluently; under the Compact of Free Association, citizens of the Federated States of Micronesia, the Republic of Palau, and the Republic of the Marshall Islands may volunteer

nodes.name: Background
nodes.data: Thirteen of Britain's American colonies broke with the mother country in 1776 and were recognized as the new nation of the United States of America following the Treaty of Paris in 1783. During the 19th and 20th centuries, 37 new states were added as the nation expanded across the North American continent and acquired a number of overseas possessions. Two of the most traumatic experiences in the nation's history were the Civil War (1861-65), in which a northern Union of states defeated a secessionist Confederacy of 11 southern slave states, and the Great Depression of the 1930s, an economic downturn during which about a quarter of the labor force lost its jobs. Buoyed by victories in World Wars I and II and the end of the Cold War in 1991, the US remains the world's most powerful nation state. Since the end of World War II, the economy has achieved relatively steady growth, low unemployment, and rapid advances in technology.

nodes.name: Military and security forces
nodes.data:
United States Armed Forces (aka US Military): US Army (USA), US Navy (USN; includes US Marine Corps or USMC), US Air Force (USAF), US Space Force (USSF); US Coast Guard (USCG); National Guard (Army National Guard and Air National Guard) (2025)

note 1: the US Coast Guard is administered in peacetime by the Department of Homeland Security, but in wartime reports to the Navy

note 2: the Army National Guard and the Air National Guard are reserve components of their services and operate in part under state authority; the US military also maintains reserve forces for each branch

note 3: US law enforcement personnel include those of federal agencies, such as the Department of Homeland Security and Department of Justice, the 50 states, special jurisdictions, local sheriff’s offices, and municipal, county, regional, and tribal police departments

note 4: some US states have "state defense forces" (SDFs), which are military units that operate under the sole authority of state governments; SDFs are authorized by state and federal law and are under the command of the governor of each state; most are organized as ground units, but air and naval units also exist

nodes.name: Climate
nodes.data:
mostly temperate, but tropical in Hawaii and Florida, arctic in Alaska, semiarid in the great plains west of the Mississippi River, and arid in the Great Basin of the southwest; low winter temperatures in the northwest are ameliorated occasionally in January and February by warm chinook winds from the eastern slopes of the Rocky Mountains

note: many consider Mount McKinley, the highest peak in the United States, to be the world’s coldest mountain because of its combination of high elevation and its subarctic location at 63 degrees north latitude; permanent snow and ice cover over 75 percent of the mountain, and enormous glaciers, up to 45 miles long and 3,700 feet thick, spider out from its base in every direction; it is home to some of the world’s coldest and most violent weather, where winds of over 150 miles per hour and temperatures of -93˚F have been recorded.

nodes.name: Constitution
nodes.data:
history: previous 1781 (Articles of Confederation and Perpetual Union); latest drafted July - September 1787, submitted to the Congress of the Confederation 20 September 1787, submitted for states' ratification 28 September 1787, ratification completed by nine of the 13 states 21 June 1788, effective 4 March 1789

amendment process: proposed as a "joint resolution" by Congress, which requires a two-thirds majority vote in both the House of Representatives and the Senate or by a constitutional convention called for by at least two thirds of the state legislatures; passage requires ratification by three fourths of the state legislatures or passage in state-held constitutional conventions as specified by Congress; the US president has no role in the constitutional amendment process

nodes.name: Flag
nodes.data:
description: 13 equal horizontal stripes of red (top and bottom) alternating with white; a blue rectangle in the upper-left corner has 50 five-pointed white stars, arranged in nine offset horizontal rows of six stars (top and bottom) alternating with rows of five stars

meaning: the stars represent the 50 states, and the stripes represent the 13 original colonies; blue stands for loyalty, devotion, truth, justice, and friendship; red for courage, zeal, and fervency; white for purity and rectitude of conduct

note 1: sometimes referred to by its nickname of "Old Glory"

note 2: the design and colors have been the basis for a number of other flags, including Chile, Liberia, Malaysia, and Puerto Rico

nodes.name: Judicial branch
nodes.data:
highest court(s): US Supreme Court (consists of 9 justices -- the chief justice and 8 associate justices)

judge selection and term of office: president nominates and, with the advice and consent of the Senate, appoints Supreme Court justices; justices serve for life

subordinate courts: Courts of Appeal (includes the US Court of Appeal for the Federal District and 12 regional appeals courts); 94 federal district courts in 50 states and territories

note: the US court system consists of the federal court system and the state court systems; each court system is responsible for hearing certain types of cases, but neither is completely independent of the other, and the systems often interact

nodes.name: Geography - note
nodes.data:
note 1: world's third-largest country by size (after Russia and Canada) and by population (after China and India); Mt. McKinley is the highest point (6,190 m; 20,308 ft) in North America, and Death Valley is the lowest point (-86 m; -282 ft)

note 2: the western US coast and the southern coast of Alaska lie along the Ring of Fire, which is a belt bordering the Pacific Ocean that contains about 75% of the world's volcanoes and up to 90% of the world's earthquakes

note 3: the Aleutian Islands are a chain of volcanic islands that divide the Bering Sea (north) from the main Pacific Ocean (south); they extend about 1,800 km (1,118 mi) westward from the Alaskan Peninsula; the archipelago consists of 14 larger islands, 55 smaller islands, and hundreds of islets; there are 41 active volcanoes on the islands, which together form a large northern section of the Ring of Fire

note 4: Mammoth Cave, in west-central Kentucky, is the world's longest known cave system with more than 650 km (405 miles) of surveyed passageways, which is nearly twice as long as the second-longest cave system, the Sac Actun underwater cave in Mexico (see "Geography - note" under Mexico)

note 5: Kazumura Cave on the island of Hawaii is the world's longest and deepest lava-tube cave; it has been surveyed at 66 km (41 mi) long and 1,102 m (3,614 ft) deep

note 6: Bracken Cave outside San Antonio, Texas is the world's largest bat cave and the summer home to the largest colony of bats in the world; an estimated 20 million Mexican free-tailed bats roost in the cave from March to October, making it the world's largest known concentration of mammals

nodes.name: National anthem(s)
nodes.data:
title: "The Star-Spangled Banner"

lyrics/music: Francis Scott KEY/John Stafford SMITH

history: adopted 1931; during the War of 1812, Francis Scott KEY witnessed the successful American defense of Baltimore's Fort McHenry against a British naval bombardment, later writing a poem about it that would become the US national anthem; the lyrics were set to the tune of "The Anacreontic Song;" there are four verses, but only the first verse is sung

media.altText: This is an audio of the National Anthem for United States. The national anthem is generally a patriotic musical composition - usually in the form of a song or hymn of praise - that evokes and eulogizes the history, traditions, or struggles of a nation or its people. National anthems can be officially recognized as a national song by a country's constitution or by an enacted law, or simply by tradition. Although most anthems contain lyrics, some do not.

nodes.name: Elevation
nodes.data:
highest point: Mount McKinley 6,190 m (highest point in North America)

lowest point: Death Valley (lowest point in North America) -86 m

mean elevation: 760 m

note 1: Mount McKinley is one of the most striking features on the entire planet; at 20,310 feet, it is the crowning peak of the Alaska Range and the highest mountain on North America; it towers three and one-half vertical miles above its base, making it a mile taller from base to summit than Mt. Everest; McKinley's base sits at about 2,000 feet above sea level and rises over three and one-half miles to its 20,310 foot summit; Everest begins on a 14,000-foot high plain, then summits at 29,028 feet

note 2: the peak of Mauna Kea (4,207 m above sea level) on the island of Hawaii rises about 10,200 m above the Pacific Ocean floor; by this measurement, it is the world's tallest mountain -- higher than Mount Everest (8,850 m), which is recognized as the tallest mountain above sea level

nodes.name: Military - note
nodes.data:
the US military's primary missions are to deter potential enemies, provide for the defense of the US, its Territories, Commonwealths and possessions, and any areas occupied by the US, and to protect US national interests; its responsibilities are worldwide and include providing humanitarian assistance, participating in international military exercises and operations, conducting military diplomacy, and fulfilling the US's alliance and treaty commitments; the US has been a leading member of NATO since the Alliance's formation in 1949

the US military has a global presence; the separate services operate jointly under 11 regional or functionally based joint service "combatant" commands: Africa Command; Central Command, Cyber Command, European Command, Indo-Pacific Command, Northern Command, Southern Command, Space Command, Special Operations Command, Strategic Command, and Transportation Command

Congress officially created the US military in September 1789; the US Army was established in June 1775 as the Continental Army; after the declaration of independence in July 1776, the Continental Army and the militia in the service of Congress became known collectively as the Army of the United States; when Congress ordered the Continental Army to disband in 1784, it retained a small number of personnel that would form the nucleus of the 1st American Regiment for national service formed later that year; both the US Navy and the US Marines were also established in 1775, but the Navy fell into disuse after the Revolutionary War, and was reestablished by Congress in 1794; the first US military unit devoted exclusively to aviation began operations in 1913 as part of the US Army; the Army Air Corps (AAC) was the US military service dedicated to aerial warfare between 1926 and 1941; the AAC became the US Army Air Forces in 1941 and remained as a combat arm of the Army until the establishment of the US Air Force in 1947 (2025)

nodes.name: Space program overview
nodes.data: has a large, comprehensive space program and is one of the world’s top space powers; builds, launches, and operates space launch vehicles (SLVs)/rockets and the full spectrum of spacecraft, including interplanetary probes, manned craft, reusable rockets, satellites, space stations, and space planes/shuttles; has an astronaut program and a corps of astronauts; researching and developing a broad range of other space-related technologies, including advanced telecommunications and optics, navigational aids, propulsion, and robotics; has launched orbital or lander probes to the Sun and all the planets in the solar system, as well as to asteroids and beyond the solar system; has dozens of international missions and projects, including with Canada, Japan, Russia, South Korea, and the ESA; as of January 2026, 60 countries had signed onto the US-led Artemis Accords to enhance the governance of civil exploration and use of outer space; the US commercial space industry is one of the world’s largest and is active across the spectrum of US government space programs; US commercial companies conduct the majority of NASA and US military space launches (2026)

nodes.name: Key space-program milestones
nodes.data:
1958-1963 - Project Mercury first manned space flights

1961-1963 - Project Gemini (longer-duration manned flights in preparation for Moon landings)

1963-1971 - Project Apollo Moon landings (world's first manned landing on the Moon, 1969)

1964 - launched first successful Mars probe (Mariner)

1965-1979 - operated Skylab space station  

1977 - began launching Voyager probes to Jupiter, Saturn, and beyond the solar system

1980s-2011 - operated Space Shuttle program (world’s first re-usable space orbiters)

1990 - launched Hubble Space Telescope

1993 - began participating in International Space Station project

2003 - launched surface rover vehicles (Spirit and Opportunity) to Mars 

2011 - launched orbital probe (Juno) to Jupiter 

2016 - launched OSIRIS-REx mission to retrieve asteroid sample (landed on asteroid Bennu in 2020 and returned with sample in 2023)

2017 - initiated Artemis lunar landing project

2019 - initiated Gateway lunar orbital station project

2021 - launched James Webb Space Telescope (ESA contributed launch vehicle and launch site); surface rover vehicle (Perseverance) with robot helicopter (Ingenuity) successfully landed on surface of Mars

2024 - successfully placed a commercial lander on the Moon and launched probe (Europa Clipper) to study Jupiter's Europa moon
